Topic.Title: Tim Cook made an almost fatal mistake.

Message.Msg: 100 Billion dollars don't mean when you can't make anything without depending on others. The Apple fog is blocking your brain functions. If Apple was a small company, they would have more options on their supply chain. Apple's supply chain must be able to handle quality and quantity with every part being the same in every way. I am a manufacturing engineer, I design, build prototypes and get the contracts. There is no guarantee that once a product goes into production the quality will be the same as the prototypes. If you order parts from China and those parts are not to print, someone higher up in the company will say use those parts because the turn around time from China is about 15 weeks. Samsung has been a great company for Apple, their abliity to give Apple both quality and huge quantity of parts is something you don't find in most companies.

Message.Title: Apple v. Samsung: Did the jury blow the Galaxy Tab verdict?
Message.Msg: If so, the judge may have to step in and play her Rule 50 trump card iPad and Galaxy Tab 10.1 FORTUNE -- A widely cited Groklaw thread has pointed out several inconsistencies in the jury's multipart verdict in the landmark Apple v. Samsung case, but one is particularly striking. As Villanova Law School Professor Michael Risch put it: "How did the Galaxy Tab escape design patent infringement? This was the only device to be preliminarily enjoined (on appeal no less), and yet it was the one of the few devices to be spared the sledgehammer." Some initial reports used the fact that the jury let the Tab off the hook -- despite the fact that its design seemed a clear imitation of the iPad's -- as proof that the verdict was not a rubber-stamp victory for Apple (AAPL). Groklaw's Pamela Jones, by contrast, took it as evidence that the entire verdict was "a farce" and won't hold up under scrutiny. Apple, for its part, immediately appealed that element of the verdict -- one of the few that didn't go its way -- and at least one expert thinks there's a good chance it may prevail. The mechanism by which that would happen is called Rule 50. It allows a judge to issue a directed verdict when the evidence permits only one reasonable conclusion -- a conclusion different from the one the jury reached. Directed verdicts are relatively uncommon, says Christopher Carani, a design law expert at McAndrews Held & Malloy. But in this case, he says, "Apple's argument may have some traction and Judge [Lucy] Koh may well exercise this super-charged trump card in Apple's favor." Like Professor Risch, he notes that Judge Koh had already granted a preliminary injunction against the Galaxy Tab 10.1 -- a ruling that required a higher burden of proof than the questions of infringement and dilution the jury was asked to decide. "Samsung appears to have created a [tablet] design that is likely to deceive an ordinary observer," she wrote, citing one of the criteria for dilution, "inducing him to purchase one supposing it to be the other." Moreover, adds Carani, the language Judge Koh used in describing the Samsung tablet -- "virtually indistinguishable," ''looks almost identical" and "looks virtually identical" -- is even stronger than the "substantially the same" standard the jury was asked to apply... "Keep an eye on Apple's Rule 50 motion for a directed verdict on the jury's finding of non-infringement on the tablet design patent," says design law expert Carani. "She just might grant it."

Message.Title: my realistic take on apple.....
Message.Msg: i think the run up for apple wont start in earnest until next week, after the long weekend. i would look for probably another 3%-4% premium to todays price. yesterday was a good profit taking opportunity, if you are a trader. i sold all my shares at the close last night, granted in hindsight i should've done it in the morning for a bigger gain...... i'm looking to build up my position again in the 670 area, i'm thinking there will be a good chance of that towards the end of the week. theres usually some kind of sell off into a long weekend. i have to say even though i'm a bull on apple, some of the long predictions on this board are insanely optimistic to say the least......i don't think the pps will really start to move until the 5 is out and prove to be a real gem (which i have no doubt it will be), even then keep in mind the stock price has already gone up 15% since the earning miss. so to me some of that postive expectation has already been baked in.......

Message.Title: Apple Versus Samsung
Message.Msg: I found an old article from 2006, and here is the key fact: "The BlackBerry dominates mobile business communications. Analysts estimate that Research in Motion has 70 percent to 80 percent of the mobile e-mail market." You see, folks, Apple was once sitting in the EXACT SAME POSITION as Samsung and Google. That is, on the outside looking in. They were looking at RIM, the dominant king of mobile of the hottest trend, the mobile email market. However, Apple's answer to "How do *we* get in this market?" was VERY different from what Samsung and Google did. Apple made their phone so different in every way that you couldn't confuse the two, literally, if you were blind. It was a completely different form factor, with completely different software and completely new options. Samsung and Google chose not to take this road. They chose not to follow Apple and take FIVE YEARS to perfect a new product like Apple did with the iPhone. Nope, they just blatantly copied and dared stand behind a fraudulent product. And let me say this ... the current verdict in the recent case SUCKS. Apple should be awarded every penny of profit that Samsung made off of what the judge decides are copied phones. Fast forward to today, and people wonder why Apple took so long to release iPhone 5. I think I know and it's EXACTLY why the 4S was released last year, rather than the 5. For once, they decided to let Samsung go first and not allow them to copy their latest iPhone. What did Samsung come up with on their own? They came up with a feature that follows your eyes. Boy, THAT is something I can't live without! I expect the next iPhone to completely blow the plastic, eye-following Galaxy S III out of the water. Heck, that phone is neck and neck with the 4S, it just has a bigger form factor and 4G. As an investor in Apple, which I am, I'll defer to what my friend said the other day. "Man, after following a little bit of that trial, I'm kinda embarrassed to own this phone (Galaxy S II). I think I'll try something different for my next phone. I'm done with Samsung." Thankfully, the judge in the Apple versus Samsung case is NOT done with them. Hammer them, Lucy, and hammer them hard. And remind them how Apple *innovated* and took down the Blackberry ... something no one thought was possible.

Topic.Title: Apple Versus Samsung

Message.Msg: Thank you, Bill. I'm just sick and tired of the illogical battle cry about how "The consumers lose because of this verdict." We have HISTORY *and* FACTS to show us that this is simply not the case. Bring some new, refreshing, easier to use and better to the table and the consumers will come. Copy something, make it cheap, lower the price, and basically flush down the years of research and development down the toilet that *another* company spent, and you will have a jury find you guilty. This isn't rocket science. I just can't see how ANYONE could follow that trial and not see how Samsung copied the iPhone. They made it look the same, act the same, used the same colors and even copied most of the icons and their placement. Make no mistake about it, though. In the end, this seems to have fired up the Apple team and kept them hungry. Apple will continue to dominate in profitability and when their market share swells even a little bit, they're going to continue to reap what they've sewn ... profits from the greatest software, inside the sleekest and best made phones in the world. Couple this with the iOS ecosystem, and you're left with the only company that allows seamless integration across one product line. And that's why they dominate.

Message.Title: The Apple vs. Samsung "lawer war" is unproductive for everybody
Message.Msg: Apple vs. Samsung. I have been dollar cost accumulation of both AAPL and PANL stock for over five years and have been waiting for a merging of these two technologies. I do not have at this time any Samsung stock. This "war" with Samsung is frustrating for me because I view it as a delay of Apple eventually adopting the newer, better, energy saving OLED screen technology into its product lines? Will Samsung be able to charge AAPL for "slavishly" copying the Galaxy NOTE and NOTE2, if Apple develops a larger screen phone and or AMOLED screen? Will this put AAPL at risk for "slavishly" copying a large screen TV that looks like the 55inch 3D AMOLED TV that both Samsung and LG are putting in stores latter this year? Will APPL become "locked out" from competing in the "massive energy savings" of OLED screen technologies that will soon ( within 5 years) be one of the largest dollar business? It takes about five years for a single oil well to be approved, drilled, and producing refined energy. OLED lighting adaption is just beginning, but this new technology will eventually save more home, business, street energy dollars, year over year, at zero pollution risk, than any new Gulf oil wells licensed to be drilled over the next ten years. Will AAPL be able to produce any revenues from this new OLED technology if they continue to "war" with Samsung, the leading, largest adaptor, developer of OLED screens and lighting? Is AAPL injuring future revenue growth and impending stock price increases by continuing this " lawyer induced war" and slapping the face of Samsung and Universal Display?

Message.Title: Just getting Started!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Message.Msg: Apple (AAPL), riding high after a jury ruled that competitor Samsung had infringed on its intellectual property, filed papers Monday to ban U.S. sales of eight older Samsung smartphone product, including the Galaxy S 4G and the Droid Charge; Samsung's top-selling Galaxy S III was excluded in patent lawsuit. The news helped drive shares of Apple to another record high on Monday and the stock has gained more than 66 percent since January. Josh Brown, vice president of investments at Fusion Analytics and author of The Reformed Broker blog, says Apple's run "is not finished" and his July call that the Cupertino, California-based company was poised for a "really big" second-half rally seems to be right. Investors are pouring money into the iPhone maker because "this is the stock that when people don't know what to do, they go to Apple," he tells The Daily Ticker's Aaron Task and Henry Blodget. Hedge funds in particular have been increasing their stake in Apple over the past few weeks. It's becoming "a notorious hedge fund hotel," Brown quips. About 230 hedge funds hold a large position in Apple and that could number could rise to 350 in weeks according to Brown. Major market indexes may be hovering near all-time highs but many sectors are lagging and Apple presents one of the surest bets for hedge funds and portfolio managers who are underperforming the market. "Apple is like the 'catch me up' vehicle," Brown notes. It's "the stock that moves the chains." Apple stock took a hit when it reported lackluster fiscal third-quarter results last month and has rebounded partly on the hype surrounding its release of the iPhone 5, which could be announced on Sept. 12. Brown says Wall Street insiders are following the stock closely for other reasons than just its rising stock price. It reveals more about consumers than monthly consumer surveys, he notes, and has become "psychologically important" for the markets. Consumer confidence may be at nine-month lows but consumers are still spending, even on high-priced Apple products, Brown says.

Topic.Title: Appletards can't comprehend the law of large numbers

Message.Msg: This is actually a legitimate concern, but if you understand it so well, why don`t you go on and explain it as relates to AAPL and its future growth instead of just throwing out your prophecy? To exceed the inflation adjusted market cap that MSFT reached in 1999, AAPL would have to reach about 900 a share. P/E is far far lower than other companies that have crumpled under the this phenomena (or a form of it). Niether the US nor the world macro is bubbling now as it was during the tech bubble (AAPL is demonstrating real performance despite the macro). Market share has lots of room to expand. These are all viable parts of the equation that makes it different from previous large-number collapses. Margins? Commoditization? Antitrust issues? These COULD all become legitimate factors effecting the share price--but, if, how and when are the questions, not blind stabs at certainty (leave that for day trading LOL). But I don`t see anyone here talking about any of these in a serious way--phrases like pos, pig, iphlop, tards etc. do more to alienate real discussion than bring any sort of cogent consideration that might otherwise be possible. It`s not that I`m squeamish about baseness, juvenility or vulgarity--I`m all of those things and more, but here it just seems to sidetrack at best and preempt at worst. I personally think AAPL has at lest 9 good months left and probably at least 18 months left...and realistically 2 to 4 good years left before it becomes a nice milk cow dividend stock...most AAPL bulls think it`s more like 12 years. I hope it is, but I can`t wrap my head around that. I can`t think beyond a price of 830, though 1000 certainly seems doable. On paper, even prices like 1200 and 2000 seem reachable (though I`m not ready to proclaim the soundness of that level). But if you`re not actually an aaplmaggottard, by all means illuminate us. It could be very interesting.

Message.Title: Obama's the Extremist, Not Romney
Message.Msg: President Obama's casting of Mitt Romney as extreme is one of the most glaring incidents of political projection in the modern era. Romney doesn't approach extremism in substance, style or disposition. Obama swims in it. In an interview with The Associated Press, Obama said Romney has locked himself into "extreme positions" on economic and social issues and would implement them if in office. Accusing Romney of extremism is just another arrow in Obama's fantasy quiver, because reality just doesn't help him. Romney is anything but extreme, and no serious political analyst believes otherwise. He is certainly extremely bullish on America, American business and the free enterprise system, and he doubtlessly wants to move the nation extremely away from the disastrous course on which Obama is taking it, but that's about the extent of his extremism. Romney's policies are right of center, to be sure, but not extreme, except from the perspective of a radical leftist, which brings us to Obama. Let's use Obama's bill of particulars against Romney as a yardstick to measure his own place on the political spectrum — as if it weren't painfully obvious. Obama says Romney is locked into extreme positions on economic issues because Romney favors across-the-board tax cuts that "would mostly help the rich." Obama discredits himself in the very words of his charge. If the cuts are across-the-board, they don't mostly favor the rich. In fact, Romney — to my disappointment, by the way — is suggesting reducing deductions for upper-income earners. Obama, on the other hand, apparently believes that the bottom 49.5 percent of income earners are getting ripped off because they are paying zero income taxes. He must think his actions in expanding the public sector, increasing the food stamp rolls, and removing the work requirement for welfare are moderate. Obama says Romney is extreme for not signing on to his quixotic wind energy hallucinations — as if anyone who doesn't believe in the government's throwing away billions more at failed and scandalous green energy experiments is the extremist — as opposed to recklessly implementing such policies when the nation has one foot in the bankruptcy door. Obama says Romney lacks "serious ideas" and refuses to "own up" to the responsibilities of what it takes to be president. These take the cake. Romney is proposing serious entitlement, tax, and spending reform, and reducing the unprecedented regulatory burden strangling the private sector. Nothing remotely extreme here. Sorry, Mr. Obama; that rabid dog will not hunt. Obama has amassed deficits in excess of $1 trillion in each of his four years. He has not produced a budget that would yield deficits below that threshold in the next decade. He has not even presented a plan to reform entitlements, has obstructed Republican reform bills and has saddled us with a brand-new budget-busting entitlement (Obamacare). His own budgets failed to get a single vote — not even a Democratic vote. Extremism? How about Obama's serious ideas? The only idea Obama has come up with since 2008 has been government spending. There is no evidence he can even ponder economic solutions straying from that nightmare.

Message.Title: Another AAPL blow to the copycats Samsung -Europe wide preliminary injuction of Samsung Galaxy smartphones
Message.Msg: The Rechtbank’s-Gravenhage (a Dutch court in the city of The Hague) today issued a formally Europe-wide preliminary injunction against Samsung’s Galaxy S, Galaxy S II and Ace smartphones — but not the Galaxy tablets — at Apple’s request,” Florian Mueller reports for FOSS Patents. “The decision follows a hearing held on August 10 and 11, 2011.” “According to a statement quoted by the BBC, Samsung appears to be determined to modify its software in order to steer clear of the infringement identified by the court [EP 2059868 - which outlines an interface for viewing and navigating photographs on a touchscreen phone],” Mueller reports. “The decision will take effect in seven weeks, i.e., mid October. That is consistent with what the judge said at the hearing, and that date didn’t change even though the decision was handed ahead of time. The court apparently has the expectation that Samsung should be able to modify its software in the meantime in order to steer clear of infringement.” Let Justice run its course

Message.Title: AAPL or SLV?
Message.Msg: The probability that silver prices fall is low, but the upside is large and probable. As a currency, silver (and gold) are money that cannot be printed. Global currencies are in a cycle of competitive devaluation. Countries seek to gain trade advantages by printing more money. As a country prints more money, its currency gets devalued making its goods and services cheaper to foreigners. No other intelligent country is going to sit idly while this happens so they in turn are incented to print as well. Further, the current EU crises will end in one of 2 ways. 1. EU break up -- mass fear and lack of demand for euros will flow into precious metals. 2. EU crises is solved -- most likely through massive bailouts (printing money). With each round of easing, the only "currency" that retains/gains value is gold and silver. So essentially, this is a heads I win, tails you lose proposition. Silver loses value is if countries stop printing money in unison. This is would involve breaking a positive feedback loop (competitive devaluation), go against the competitive nature of human beings, and involove an improbable level of global cooperation. So the next question is... Why silver and not gold? Gold is only a fear asset and silver is not. Gold does not share the same industrial uses that silver benefits from. Gold is used to make jewelery and to hold in times of fear... that's it. Silver is the most conductive metal on earth, is used in solar cells, electronics, cars, silverware, medical applications, and even odorless socks. The industrial uses of silver give it a price floor. On the other hand, gold has no industrial use so its value is purely psychological. Since the value of gold is psychological I cannot think of a price floor for the asset. This situation is especially precarious when gold is at/near all-time highs.

Topic.Title: Appletards can't comprehend the law of large numbers

Message.Msg: Well the actual PEG ratio is ridiculously low. The EPS has grown more than 70% for years now, while the PE has remained around 15, which means the stock isn't growing as fast as the EPS. At some point people will realize it is way undervalued. The PEG will likely approach FV once Apple becomes more of a cash cow. Its hard for people to understand a company growing earnings by over 100% some quarters (y-o-y). Esp so many quarters within the past 4 years. They just can't get themselves to buy it up to its true value, so then it will take on a higher value once it becomes a more steady stock. I think once the growth run is over, the PE will creep back up to 27 (the 10 year average prior to recession). Assuming that Apple can get to $65 share (at least) that gives you an eventual price over $1700/shr. But who knows how long this process will take (if it happens). Its all guess work.

Message.Title: Chinese people are among the hardest working people in the world
Message.Msg: I know I have seen for myself how industrious they are. I will never forget my visit to Beijing a few years ago. Having said that there government doesn't protect individualism or innovation. It also doesn't care if you copy other peoples design(especially American). This has been and is my only concern about Apples prospects in mainland China. There will always be the upper class that will want to be seen with an authentic Apple but many others will probably be willing to carry a copy. That being said Apple is far from pricing in the growth that they will see in China. I am just saying that I don't think the growth will be as dynamic as it would have been if China was more like the west.

BTW the Chinese people believe Americans to be their best friends and allies, which is totally different than the two govts act. They are a capitalist country run by 10% of the population that are communists. A reason in itself to protect our rights especially the right to bear arms They have hardly anyway to overthrow the govt that will run you over with tanks. Think about that when you go to the polls when Obama/Hilliary just signed an UN resolution to take away the US citizens guns but it never had a chance in congress.

Message.Title: Apple iPhone 5 coming amid Samsung sell offs
Message.Msg: Apple's victory in its landmark legal battle may have created a wave of uncertainty for owners of Samsung smartphones -- many are dumping them. A nine person jury on Friday found Samsung guilty of infringement in the patent case over designs and software of Apple's iPads and iPhones. Apple won an injunction that covers 28 Samsung models that could be banned from U.S. sales. Since the verdict, resale site Gazelle.com has seen an over 50% uptick in sales of Samsung phones from customers, a move that comes ahead of Apple's widely rumored iPhone 5 launch, expected in mid-September. It is also widely expected that Apple will unveil an iPad mini about the same time. "The spike in Samsung (sellers) was right around the court verdict," says Anthony Scarsella, chief gadget officer at Gazelle.com. Apple on Monday singled out eight phones it would like banned. The company has asked the court for injunctions on Samsung's Galaxy S 4G, Galaxy S2 (AT&T), Galaxy S2 Skyrocket, Galaxy S2 (T-Mobile), Galaxy S2 Epic 4G, Galaxy S Showcase, Droid Charge and Galaxy Prevail. Apple earlier was granted an injunction banning Samsung's Galaxy Tab 10.1 tablet. The Galaxy S II Epic that's in Apple's legal cross hairs saw a 10% drop in prices on the mobile device resale site, says Scarsella. "I think consumers in general could be shying away from purchasing these devices going forward. Some people are panicking," he says. Concerns run that Samsung smartphones may get inferior software updates and a degraded touch experience. The jury verdict against Samsung found that some touch functions of its software, powered by Google's Android operating system, infringed on Apple's patents. If Samsung does not win an appeal of the verdict at the federal circuit court in Washington, D.C., it will have to remove or work around the legal claims on Apple's innovations.

Message.Title: Has anyone on AT&T or Verizon checked out the new rates?
Message.Msg: A few months back Verizon introduced all you can eat text and voice plans that include a data bundle (2g, 4giig etc). Interestingly enough, AT&T followed with the same about a week later. The plans are smart for the carriers because they cut free third party apps off at the knees, eg, who cares if you iMessage or text because your already paying for an all you can eat text plan. Same for voice. Now, when you go to upgrade a device ( whether it be Samsung, Apple, Blackberry) in order to get the subsidy, you must change to a new plan. I think in most cases, the new plans are substantially more than most people are paying today.---curious if others are in the same boat on that. Interesting that they did this on the eve of iPhone 5 (IMO). I think their betting on most people changing plans without thinking twice about leaving to sprint or somewhere else because they want the phone bad enough, In my case, rate would go from 120 and change including taxes to about 2 bills. I'd get all you can eat voice and text, but don't use that much to pay for it. Anyone else check out what it would mean to them? Google " Forbes AT&T and Verizon". There's an article on it. Anyway, wonder if it will backlash on them. Probably not, most people are sheep, even in this economy, Ggggggggg
